publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Strenuus et Fortis causisq; Philippus &c.
Harley ye Nation's Great Support,
Returning home one day from Court,
His mind with Publick cares possess'd,
All Europe's business in his breast,
Observ'd a Parson near Whitehall
Cheapning old Authors on a Stall:
The Priest was pretty well in case,
And shew'd some humour in his face;
Look'd with an easy careless meen,
A perfect Stranger to ye Spleen.
Of Size that might a Pulpit fill,
But more inclining to Sit Still.My Lord who (if a Man may Say't)
Loves mischeif better than his meat,
Was now dispos'd to crack a Jest,
And bid Friend Lewis go in Quest:
(This Lewis is a cunning Shaver
And very much in Harley's favour)
In Quest who might this Parson be,
What was his name, of what degree;
If possible to learn his Story,
And whether He were Whig or Tory.Lewis his Patron's humour knows,
Away upon his Errand goes;
And quickly did ye matter Sift,
Found out That This was Doctr: Swift;
A Clergyman of Speciall note
For shunning those of his own coat;
Which made his Brethren of ye Gown
Take care betimes to run him down;
No Libertine, nor over nice;
Addicted to no Sort of Vice;
Went where he pleas'd, Said what he thought,
Not rich, but ow'd no man a Groat;
In State opinions á la Mode,
He hated Wharton like a Toad;
Had giv'n ye Faction many a Wound,
And libell'd all ye Junta round;
Kept Company with men of Wit,
Who often father'd what he writ;
His works were hawk'd in ev'ry Street,
But Seldom rose above a Sheet:
Of late indeed ye Paper Stamp
Did very much his Genius cramp;
And Since he could not Spend his fire,
He now intended to retire.Said Harley I desire to know
From his own mouth if this be So.
Step to ye Doctor Straight & Say
I'd have him dine with me to day.
Swift seem'd to wonder what he meant,
Nor would beleive my Lord had sent;
So never offer'd once to Stir,
But coldly Said──Your Servant SṛDoes he refuse me Harley cry'd?
He does──with insolence & pride.Some few days after Harley spies
The Doctor fasten'd by ye eyes,
At Charing Cross, among ye Rout
Where painted Monsters are hung out:
He pull'd ye String, & Stopp'd ye Coach,
Beck'ning ye Doctor to approach.
Swift who could neither fly nor hide,
Came sneaking to ye Chariot Side;
And offer'd many a lame excuse,
He never meant ye least abuse──
My Lord ye Honour you design'd──
Extreamly proud──But I had din'd──
I'm Sure I never should neglect──
No man alive has more respect──Well──I shall think of that no more
If you'll be Sure to come at four:The Doctor now obeys ye Summons,
Likes both his Company & Commons:
Displays his talent, Sits till ten,
Next day invited comes again:
Soon grows domestick, Seldom fails
Either at morning or at meals:
Came early & departed late,
In short ye Gudgeon took ye bait.
My Lord would carry on ye Jest,
And down to Windsor takes his guest.Swift much admires ye place & air,
And longs to be a Canon there;
In Summer round ye Park to ride,
In Winter never to reside.
A Canon! That's a place too mean:
No Doctor──You shall be a Dean:
Two dozen Canons round your Stall,
And you ye Tyrant o'er them all:
You need but cross ye Irish seas,
To live in plenty pow'r & ease.
Poor Swift departs; & what is worse,
With borrow'd money in his purse;
Travels at least an hundred leagues,
And Suffers numberless fatigues.Suppose him now a Dean compleat,
Devoutly lolling in his Seat;
The Silver verge with decent pride
Stuck underneath his cushion Side.Suppose him gone thrô all vexations,
Patents, Installments, Abjurations,
First fruits, & tenths, & Chapter treats,
Dues, payments, fees, demands, & cheats,
The wicked Laity's contriving
To keep poor Clergymen from thriving.
Now all ye Doctors money Spent
His Tenants wrong him in his Rent;
The Farmers spitefully combin'd
Force him to take his Tyths in kind
And 1Dean's Steward Parvisol discounts arrears
By bills for taxes & repairs.Poor Swift with all his losses vex'd,
Not knowing where To turn him next,
Above a thousand pounds in debt,
Takes horse, & in a mighty fret
Rides day & night at such a rate
He soon arrives at Harley's gate;
But was So dirty pale & thin
Old 2Ld Trear's Porter. Read would hardly let him in.Said Harley wellcome Revd Dean,
What makes your Worship look So lean?
Why Sure you wont appear in Town
With that old Wig, & rusty gown?
I doubt your heart is Set on pelf
So much yt You neglect your Self;
What──I suppose now Stocks are high
You've some good Purchase in your eye;
Or is your money out at use?Truce Good my Lord──I beg a truce──
The Doctor in a passion cry'd,
Your raillery is misapplied;
I have experience dearly bought,
You know I am not worth a Groat:
But you resolv'd to have yor Jest,
And 'twas a folly to contest;
Then since you now have done your worst,
Pray leave me where you found me first.170-490L
